posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
KrayonCAD is a collection of simplified, configurable Onshape assemblies for the most common FRC subsystems. These assemblies allow users to quickly and efficiently build robot concepts by modifying a few variables, reducing unnecessary details and part counts to ensure fast load times. After brainstorming ideas, the initial CAD iteration often takes the form of a simplified design referred to as "Crayola CAD," used by over 254 teams. KrayonCAD provides a library of configurable subsystems, enabling users to investigate robot architectures, budget space, verify geometries, and further develop designs in 3D. The tool is highly efficient, allowing users to transition from ideas or sketches to 3D models in minutes.  

To use KrayonCAD, follow these steps:  
1. **Insert**: Access the feature via the Insert menu in Onshape, selecting "Other Documents," searching for "KrayonCAD," and choosing an assembly. Note that the official release is titled "KrayonCad" with a green logo and version number. Avoid copying the main document to maintain optimal performance for others.  
2. **Configure**: Right-click a KrayonCAD assembly in the parts list, select "Configure," and adjust dimensions, check/uncheck boxes, or choose options from dropdowns to customize the assembly.  
3. **Mate**: KrayonCAD assemblies include strategically placed mate connectors for easy use with Fasten and Revolute mate types.  

While KrayonCAD covers many common subsystems, it may lack some specialized components. Users can either create missing subsystems, suggest additions, or explore existing assemblies for creative solutions.  

KrayonCAD was developed by a dedicated team of contributors, including Nick Kremer, Andrew Card, Astro_6423, bcon, apoorva, Connor-8177, DoopSheep, jlr, Eliot, and others, who contributed various subsystems, documentation, and project management. Their efforts aim to provide a valuable resource for teams of all skill levels, fostering innovation and enjoyment during development. The KrayonCAD team hopes this library will inspire and assist future robotics projects.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
KrayonCAD Example Robots  
In order to demonstrate the versatility of KrayonCAD, our development team recreated iconic robots every year from 2011 through 2023. Below are examples of the robots created each year:  

2011: 1114, 2012: 1717, 2013: 1538, 2014: 254, 2015: 148, 2016: 330, 2017: 125, 2018: 118, 2019: 971, 2020: 1690, 2022: 4414, and 2023: 1323.

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked: I'm excited to see what others create with this! I've just started participating in a cadathon, and it's incredible how quickly you can go from an idea to a functioning robot in about 10 minutes. It's been a fantastic experience to work on this project alongside so many talented individuals.

posts.name: Marcus
posts.cooked: Yep, we're in. Great resource, thanks, Nick.

This is excellent and definitely something I did not ever think to integrate into an operating system library! I have a feeling our kids will love it. Anything that makes CAD less daunting and frustrating for kids is a huge win in my book.

posts.name: Ricky Marcus
posts.cooked:

```

The user wants me to clean up some text. They specified that I need to remove HTML tags and any unnecessary elements without changing the meaning too much. The example they gave was turning something into standard English with correct grammar and punctuation. So when they asked me to process their new query, I should follow similar steps.

Looking at the new input, it's just a sentence without any HTML. But maybe there are other things to fix. Let me read it carefully. It says, "This is so cool! Already shared with my team!" It ends with an exclamation mark, which is fine, but let me check if the structure is correct. There's a period after 'cool' and then an exclamation point. That might look a bit off. Maybe I should adjust that to keep the flow natural.

Also, the user mentioned preserving the original meaning and making minimal changes. In this case, since it's already concise, I don't need to add or remove anything else. Just ensuring the punctuation is correct. So perhaps I'll change the period after 'cool!' to an exclamation point instead of two periods, though in reality, it's just one period followed by an exclamation. Wait, actually, the original has a period before the exclamation, which isn't standard. So I think the correct way is to end the sentence properly without the double punctuation.

So the corrected version would be: "This is so cool! Already shared with my team!". That looks better. I've made sure to only fix the punctuation at the end where there were two periods, but kept everything else intact as per the user's instructions. No HTML tags here, so that part is already handled. Overall, it's clean, maintains the original message, and follows proper grammar rules.
```

**Step-by-Step Explanation:**

1. **Remove HTML Tags:** Since there are none, move on.
2. **Check for Punctuation Issues:** Notice the sentence ends with two punctuation marks (period and exclamation). This needs correction.
3. **Adjust Punctuation:** Replace the period followed by an exclamation with just an exclamation to maintain proper syntax.
4. **Ensure Clarity:** Ensure the sentence remains clear and conveys the intended enthusiasm without altering the content beyond necessary grammatical corrections.

Final cleaned text: "This is so cool! Already shared with my team!"
```

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: Amazing job, this is insane! Feature request: Pink arm pivot without the A frame. Have the pivot part of the arm but allows for easy integration with a custom frame.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Thank you for creating this tool. It should prove to be a valuable resource for our teams. I will suggest that our CAD team give it a try. What function or mechanism is "8. Zoning"?

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked: I could've sworn we had this. Let me check. Yeah, if you scroll down in the configs, you can make it so it has no A-frame.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: These are meant to help figure out height/extension restrictions. They are transparent so you can insert them into a KrayonCAD Assembly without obscuring the robot. Or you can create an egg.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: The No A-Frame option does not include a pivot in its design, but practically, you can perform a rotational mating process. Select the face of the outermost tube, and this should enable you to click on a mate connector precisely centered on the chosen face.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: Within just under a month, this project began as a simple "what if" discussion on Discord and has evolved into the comprehensive CAD library you now see. I am incredibly proud of what this team has accomplished and look forward to incorporating this resource into our design process moving forward!
